citation.abstract: The Leuser ecosystem in northern Sumatra is home to some of the world's rarest and best-loved animals. Thanks to a new government moratorium on land clearing, conservationists have enjoyed a big win.
citation.title: Good news for the only place on Earth where tigers, rhinos, orangutans and elephants live together

facebook.title: Good news for the only place on Earth where tigers, rhinos, orangutans and elephants live together
facebook.summary: The Leuser ecosystem in northern Sumatra is home to some of the world's rarest and best-loved animals. Thanks to a new government moratorium on land clearing, conservationists have enjoyed a big win.

facebook.title: Good news for the only place on Earth where tigers, rhinos, orangutans and elephants live together
facebook.summary: Some good news for the Leuser ecosystem in northern Sumatra, Indonesia – the last place on Earth where tigers, orangutans, rhinoceros and elephants still live alongside one another. #forceforgood

facebook.title: Good news for the only place on Earth where tigers, rhinos, orangutans and elephants live together
facebook.summary: The Leuser ecosystem in northern Sumatra is home to some of the world's rarest and best-loved animals. Thanks to a new government moratorium on land clearing, conservationists have enjoyed a big win.

facebook.title: Good news for the only place on Earth where tigers, rhinos, orangutans and elephants live together
facebook.summary: The government of Aceh Province – which controls most of the Leuser ecosystem and has been subjected to withering criticism for its schemes to destroy much of the region’s forests for oil palm, rice and mining expansion while opening it up with a vast road

news.title: Good news for the only place on Earth where tigers, rhinos, orangutans and elephants live together
news.summary: Today, at least, we can celebrate a very significant victory for conservation, and give credit to the many people who have worked to raise the profile of Leuser, including the actor Leonardo DiCaprio.

news.title: 2016, the year that was: Environment + Energy
news.summary: If 2015 ended on a note of hope, with the successful conclusion of the Paris climate talks, the overriding impression of 2016 is that last year’s optimism has been answered with a large reality check.

news.title: People, palm oil, pulp and planet: four perspectives on Indonesia's fire-stricken peatlands
news.summary: Peat means different things to different people. To many Irish people, it means fuel.
